data.text: Ridiculous! Ortlieb Seat Pack Sags!

Apologies- this is ridiculous! Never used a rear roll before. Tightened up all straps as much as I could but can't rectify the sag Only got light bits in their like sleeping bag, multinat and tea brewing equipment. I notice Ortlieb sell an aftermarket strap, maybe this is essential?
Maybe orange straps also through saddlerails? 🤔
data.author: Ghevaiden Il Tuono

data.text: Smaller bag or more stuff in it?
data.author: Jason Boehlke

data.text: I hated mine, returned it after one trip. Not worth the money
data.author: Ethan Johnson

data.text: There is a purple pill for that. 🤪
data.author: Surly Wojtek

data.text: Did you try to cross the straps ?
data.author: Joe Ringer II

data.text:
Without a bracket you can never really get rid of the sway. Get something like the Woho stabilizer or similar and your problem is solved: https://www.tradeinn.com/bikeinn/en/woho-x-touring-v2-stabilizer-pannier-rack/136657517/p
Woho X-Touring V2 Stabilizer Pannier Rack, Black | Bikeinn
tradeinn.com
data.author: Magnus Verbrugge

data.text: I have this and it's a game changer!
data.author: Andi Smith

data.text: me too!
data.author: Magnus Verbrugge

data.text: Too loosely packed. Cram your gear in and then roll super tight. There's simply far too much space in the bag.
data.author: Andi Smith

data.text: this
data.author: Daniel Sherer

data.text: Aftermarket strap helps, but not essential. It’s all in the art of packing and rolling as tight as possible.
data.author: Brett Alan
Brett Alan

data.text: Yes that strap is pretty essential.
data.author: Brian Morin

data.text: Never had this issue. I have the amazon version of this one. Looks like it wasn’t packed tight enough before folding the top down. Need to pack tight. Roll too tight. Then the side straps
data.author: Johnathan Stuckey

data.text: Don't you need to roll the top of the bag more - getting the contents more snugly packed, then clip up the top straps?
data.author: Dave Johnson

data.text: You gotta stuff it more tightly inside. It's very loosely stuffed. I pack it really tight and it work very well for me, never had this issue. Works without the extra strap for me
data.author: Kristina Žiaukė

data.text: You’ve got too much space in the pack - try packing everything smaller, and tighter. That’ll help dampen the sway.
data.author: Dan Grüssing

data.text: You short a strap!
data.author: Frederick W J Swanepoel

data.text: Fill it and then install.
data.author: Erick Barrios
Frederick W J Swanepoel

data.text: I have the same Ortlieb bag and it’s great. The trick it to put the nose on the ground then ram the contents in as hard as you can. Pack it super tight and it will be fine.
data.author: Paul Chignell

data.text: U need compress
data.author: Fuu Nees
Frederick W J Swanepoel

data.text: I had this happen once on a different brand bag. I have found that packing something a little longer that can act as a stiffener was helpful. I also don’t pack fully so it is not over-extended (mine is 14 ltr). Also, pack tightly with compression. As for the strap, I have found that adding a large voile strap (sp?) and cinching tightly keeps the sway to a minimum. At end of day work to keep the rear volume low.
data.author: Bill Mondock

data.text: I cut a piece of wood 6mm ply and put it in the bottom of the bag. Made all the difference.
data.author: Mark Vernon

data.text: did think about bracing it.
data.author: Peter Whitlock

data.text: Flip flops do a good job too.

data.text: put your tent poles inside 🙂

data.text: yes a wood dowel would help
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: what tent poles 😎
data.author: Mark Vernon

data.text: not the same bag but this is mine with the wood inside at the bottom. Hard stuff the bag against the wood and it’ll be super rigid

data.text: garden canes work great too

data.text: I also use a tarp, but always take a couple of tent poles as back up 🙂

data.text: that’s a good plan mate I’m considering the same

data.text: wrongly packed, there’s an air bubble so it doesn’t stay straight, open the valve before starting to compress, close the valve after compressing

data.text: and compress as much as you can - if it isnt compressed, it will bend

data.text: I usually strap mine to the wheel. Keeps it more rigid.

data.text: I had this issue same bag, I used a cut down piece of Perspex and slid it inside as a base! It worked

data.text: For real though you can get a little furring strip from Lowe's or you can even use a first aid splint in the bottom of the bag to stiffen the whole thing up

data.text: I quickly ditched mine and got a rear rack that supports panniers. No matter how I rigged it I couldn’t mountain bike in techy terrain with that.

data.text: all a matter of packing smart and tight. + it takes some tours and uses to ‚learn‘ it. The extra strap is not essential. used mine 1 year before buying the strap for the reason why not. Worth it

data.text: a ‚trick‘ i use, which may be obvious or not, after compressing and locking the mechanism, i tighten the straps on the side a bit and then repeat it 1-2 times

data.text: Wife has the same bag and packing your tent poles in it does the job perfectly. Just stuff the poles in first making sure they’re on the bottom of the bag.

data.text: You need to roll it up much tighter before attaching orange straps

data.text: It's still all wrinkled. Open the valve, roll all excess bag fabric over itself tightly, connect the orange straps and tighten them. Now close the valve.

data.text: You can also take the end of the bungee and pull it over the seatpost and it will pull the bag up even if it is overloaded. I have that bag and it works great.

data.text: I have the same bag and the same problem but I solved it by cross crossing the straps on the top with the opposite sides so it has a bit more lift and I also rely on the handlebar bag to carry part of the weight

data.text: Pack it tight - it works

data.text: Not packed/compressed properly. But I find such bags impractical anyway. Everything is shaking. no thing is really solid Looking for the alternatives.
data.author: Oliver Heigl

data.text: The aftermarket strap is expensive!! I take two bungees and hook under the pack and then hook to the seat. This is how I solved the horrible quality issues this pack has!! It really is a SHIT pack and over priced in comparison to other way better quality packs!! My spouse bought seat pack by topeak that actually does not have this issue!
data.author: Christine Warren

data.text: yeah I returned mine after one trip. Garbage. Bought Revelate, problem solved

data.text: Load adjustment and distribution is key, you need to load the heavier stuff close to the seat post

data.text: Happens to the best of us at certain times. You're thinking to much about it. If it persists talk to your doctor. Might be the tire rubber also.

data.text: I always wondered how you bonerpillppl configure your spam folder?

data.text: after 200km we all need help 🤣

data.text: I was speaking metaphorically. To date this engine is pumping quite well without out need of oil additive. We'll see if the zucks AI will be sending me "offers" now.
data.author: Trek Mike

data.text: another hint (lifehack) for seatpack owners - fix orange straps X-type, left to the right clamp, right to the left clamp (over the top of the pack). And You wan't need any extra straps. But as mentioned above - weight distribution, packing sequence and firm/soft items sequence is the key (and squeeze all the air out of the pack 🙂 )
data.author: Aleksandr Geižān

data.text: You're doing it wrong 😂.

data.text: I have the ortlieb support straps, bought them for 10 euros. They are really helpful and fix any kind of sagging issues, I think it was worth it, the bag is so expensive, 10 more euros isn’t much in comparison 😞
data.author: Tanya Dhawan

data.text: I want to add.. I’m quite short and my saddle is quite close to the tire, so they help me maintain the few 3 cm gap I have. Anything like a bungee that is stretchable would let the bag bounce down if I went on a bump At a faster speed
data.author: Tanya Dhawan

data.text: Pack tight to the front and keep the weight there.

data.text: I rode one of these bags for a year and a half with constant use. I found the strap to be essential and also helpful for holding additional gear down on top. A woho seat stabiliser or similar is also an essential for keeping horizontal sway to a minimum. Being able to add two bottle cages is an extra bonus. Enjoy the ride :)

data.text: I added a ribbed piece from a set of plastic storage bin inside the bottom my bag. The worst for me is when I don’t have enough to fill it. I do use and extra strap. I eventually ended up going to the bindle rack and a custom bag.

data.text: I never have this problem with same bag. It should work
data.author: Patty Jo STruve

data.text: Rearrange stuff inside, squize them , roll more tight and if needed (I do since I fill it up and with heavy load and I I ride a small size bike) use the additional strap. I use it for many long multiday trips, best saddle bag till now. Bf with size large also very satisfied.

data.text: Looks like it just needs filling more

data.text: This is as minimal effort as your post.
data.author: Pads Rodolfo

data.text: Looks like there's not enough stuff inside,pack it tighter,need to roll extra bag downwards tighten straps and fasten together.
data.author: Donnie Harvey

data.text: It's a matter of packing. If you don't do the effort of acking it well, you ain't gonna ride as well
data.author: Yvonne Roep

data.text: The Revelate version has a strap from the bottom of seat post up and over the stuff sack. This holds it up somewhat straight. Also, what you pack is key. I pack my cooking gear in a bag on the front forks using Gorilla clips. All clothes, sleeping bag soft stuff is stuffed in the seat pack. At the end of the day, when I go out on the Bomtrack ADV+ I use panniers. No problems other than you pack too much!
data.author: Michael Charles

data.text: ORTLIEB Outdoor Equipment look at this 🙈
data.author: Andreas Kabus

data.text: Ever used one but if it does that easily it’s a pretty shit design. There should be straps over the top of the bag to stop this sort of thing happening. Are you sure those straps you have there aren’t meant to be on top?
data.author: Aaron Koolen-Bourke

data.text: If you pack your bag normally (keep the weight near the seatpost and stuff everything thight) you will not have that problem. I once made an improvised seat pack to replace a broken rear-rack on a trip, by cutting up a 3 litre coca-cola bottle and using it as "stiff inner", put a drybag around it and strapped it with some straps to my seatpost. Worked great also. You could try to cut up a plastic bottle and use it as a stiffner plate in this bag. COuld solve your problem if it does not work out with packing your luggage the right way.
data.author: Mike Steegmans

data.text: You should be able to roll the bag up more. If not you have to rearrange the things inside. Those extra straps should not be necessary.

data.text: It should work whether half full or completely full. Pack it tightly. Soft items work best. Better still a small tent with poles gives it rigidity. Irregular-shaped items, loosely-packed can create problem as shown here.
data.author: Bryn Roberts

data.text: I think that is half the problem. There are some non-compactable items in there. Toying with the idea of stuffing the tent and sleeping bag in there without their outer bags to make it a better fit (as packing them in their proper bags makes them non compactable)
data.author: Peter Whitlock

data.text: just keep in mind you may have to stuff a wet tent at some point, and if you have it loose in a seat pack with your sleeping bag, it’ll all be wet. I like to put non compressible items in the very front, then tuck sleeping bag, layers etc to fill the space and make it “plump”
data.author: Kyle Julius

data.text: I have the same bag, just experiment a bit - believe me, it works fine, no need for extra straps.

data.text: Lol - I have the same bag, it’s never looked like that. Got to be user error!

data.text: Definitely - never used one before but picked up great tips and where I went wrong from the community.

data.text: I actually cross the straps over the top of the bag so your not clipping in on the same side. I also use a secondary strap like ortlieb sells but got it at a camping/army surplus store for $5. Its mostly to calm down any swaying

data.text: I put my tent poles in my seat pack (Ortlieb) to give it some rigid structure.

data.text: Yeah as Gert said, you need to rearrange the items inside with the heavier ones closer to the seat, And if you roll the bag in a way so that the orange strap is pulling at the opposite angle to that shown in the picture, it would make the bag more rigid and keep it away from the wheel

data.text: What's up with all the fully rigid bikepacking bike photos people are sharing. I am using one right now too, but I can't possibly continue to do so. It is so much less strenuous not getting rattled to bits while using suspension. I am going to look for a cargo suspension fork; this isn't the 1970s anymore.

data.text: I have the same pack and had a sag problem on my ritchey breakaway, not quite as severe but it was rubbing. I found that putting my Kindle at the bottom, over the join where the softer material starts gave enough support. I'll be putting a bit of light wood in next time
data.author: Guy Hallam
